Award.AbstractNarration: Through this multi-year project Delaware Technical & Community College (Delaware Tech) is endeavoring to teach its students and the community about the concepts of a sustainable society and how to incorporate renewable energy technologies (i.e., wind, solar, and biofuel) into their lifestyles. The college is achieving this goal by incorporating renewable energy topics into existing Electronics and Computer Engineering Technology, Chemistry Technology, Biotechnology and Chemical Process Operator Technology programs and by providing outreach activities to the College and local community in the form of workshops, camps, middle and high school student enrichment activities and teacher internships. In Delaware--which has mandated that by 2020, 20% of the energy sold in the state must come from renewable sources--there is a strong identifiable need for programs like these that address sustainability and renewable energy topics as they train a workforce ready for new green industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energizing STEM Education

Reducing carbon emissions, using renewable energy technology and protecting the environment are needed skills to be able to reduce our impact on the environment. In this project, various methods were used to educate students and the community about the concepts of a sustainable society and how to incorporate renewable energy technologies into their lifestyle. As a result of this project, students enrolled in the Electronics and Computer Engineering Technology, Chemistry and Chemical Process Operator Technology programs at Delaware Technical Community College are now provided hands-on learning and applied training on renewable energy equipment. Graduates and current students possess a broadened knowledge base of renewable energy which enhances their employment opportunities, in addition to adding value to their workplace. Students enrolled in other programs and the local community have the opportunity to enroll in SOC103, the college's new Sustainability and Society course. This course, developed with NSF funds, provides an understanding of sustainability and skills needed to analyze problems concerning how to reduce their environmental impact on the world around them.

The project was also able to offer workshops and summer camps at three of the college's campuses. These activities were free to the community. The youths involved in the summer camps learned about sustainability, how it relates to environmental and social advocacy and how they can apply the concepts to their daily lives. The Sustainability Speaker Series provided energy and sustainability related discussions to the community on topics such as composting, bio-char and different types of solar technology. Two summer camps were developed and offered for primary and middle-school students. Sustainability in Your Backyard offered primary school students the chance to learn what sustainability is and why it matters, explore gardening and composting and participate in a microscopic scavenger hunt. The Renewable Energy camp provided middle-school youth the opportunity to learn how to program, control and monitor wind and solar energy systems and explore engineering and design concepts in college-level laboratories. Equipment and lesson plans developed for the Renewable Energy camp were modified and now being used in EPSCOR funded camps for 13-15 year old youths.

Increasing the amount of hands-on, real-world applications related to renewable energy and sustainability concepts provided excitement and interest among  the students and the community along with gaining the knowledge of how to incorporate renewable energy technologies into their lifestyles.

The project was successful in exposing students and the community to the concepts of a sustainable society and expanded their knowledge of renewable energy and environmental sustainability.
